posts.name: Weston Gardner
Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: When running replay with the skeleton template, are you switching the simMode from SIM to REPLAY before starting replay watch?

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked:
No, I forgot to do that. After switching and running the command, the replay ran for about 11 seconds than turned to replay finished.

So I think it must be some kind of code error in my other code.

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked:
Apparantly I had to add this at the bottom of my build.gradle file: > project.compileJava.dependsOn(spotlessApply)

spotless { java { target fileTree(“.”) { include “ /*.java" exclude " /build/ ", " /build- / " } } groovyGradle { target fileTree(“.”) { include " / .gradle” exclude “ /build/ ”, “ /build-*/ ” } } json { target fileTree(“.”) { include “ /*.json" exclude " /build/ ", " /build- / " } } format “misc”, { target fileTree(“.”) { include " / .md”, “ /.gitignore" exclude " /build/ ", " /build-*/**” } } }

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked: Now I am getting a problem with the replay taking forever. When I run the command for the first time it takes around 30 seconds for an 18 second log, then when I change things in src it takes around 25 seconds to replay the log. I did make sure to declare setUseTiming(false); in the robot replay case of the constructor. any ideas on the issue?

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: How long does it take to run replay without replay watch?

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked: after doing the build and selecting the gui it goes fast only takes about 1 second

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: Replay watch is rerunning the build when you change code too, so it should closely match the time it takes to run normal replay if you include the full time. This would be equivalent to running normal replay via ./gradlew simulateJava on the command line and waiting for it to exit.

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked: Okay, I saw on the docs that when the demonstrater changed the src the replay ony took a second, is there a way to make mine go that fast as well?

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
That project was an example where normal replay only took only a few seconds. The speed is strongly related to the complexity of the project, length of the log file, and the speed of your computer. Unfortunately there just aren’t a lot of shortcuts here since replay is designed to maintain determinism, and every change can affect the entire log file.

For reference, we’re able to replay a typical match log with our 2024 code in roughly 5-10 seconds using a modern MacBook (keep in mind that replay is almost entirely single-threaded, so multi-core performance doesn’t have a major effect). However, it can take significantly longer depending on the device running the replay.

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked: I don’t think performance is an issue, I have a i9-13900H processor with 32 gigs of ram, and I also tested it with a roughly 6.2 second log, and on the first replay it took 35 seconds, and when I updated something it took aroud 26 seconds. Our project is our main robot code for the season, so it is not fully completed but also not completely simple.

posts.name: Weston Gardner
posts.cooked: ShuffleData.java (2.6 KB) We do have this as a logging system that we custom coded that basically allows for real time variable changing, and offers custom folder structuring to logging. Would that interfere with this? attatched is the class for it
